commentBody: One more reminder to vote for the Griddies. This first round of voting ends Jan 24. That‚Äôs Friday, at midnight in the Oceania time zone, according to John Ezra. But why wait and risk falling afoul of election rules? Or falling into a POTHOLE?? Head over to Eric Hougland‚Äôs at the link below. Do it now! Carpe diem! You‚Äôll be able to vote for up to 5 puzzles in each category. The ballot has descriptions and dates so you can look puzzles up in the archives to refresh your memory. https://form.jotform.com/243358842724059
too quick.  sorry not that difficult for the rebus.
Missed opportunity to make the Laura DERN clue about one of David Lynch‚Äôs works (RIP to a legend)
Not quite the Thursday challenge I expected, and hoped for, but I enjoyed it nevertheless.  I hope the only POTHOLES I see this winter will be the ones that appeared in this puzzle.
Easier than usual Thursday, not that I‚Äôm complaining. Good fun.
Certainly on the easier side for a Thursday puzzle. The rebus was an easy trick to solve.

Quite elegant‚Ä¶potholes in roads‚Ä¶.nice.

Probably too easy for a Thursday‚Ä¶.but I guess it must have been deemed too hard for a Wednesday.

Enjoyable, but way too easy for a Thursday.  I've been doing the NYT crosswords for over 40 years.  Only started paying attention to my solve times when the puzzles became solvable online.  For a long time, 30-45 minutes was not unusual for me for a Thursday puzzle.  This one took me less than 11 minutes.  And last week's wasn't much longer than that.  

I'm grateful for the puzzle creators and editors, but it seems to me that, for the past few months, the puzzles have been getting easier and easier.  

Missing the challenge is all...
An easy Thursday and as one who lives and drives in NYC, I can appreciate that all types of our roadways have potholes.  It's surprising at times to see how bad they are.
I originally had TRYST as the answer to "Arrangement for an heir" and, frankly, I think my answer is better. Or at least more funny!

Fun puzzle with lively clueing. Shout out to both Natan Last and Andy Kravis, who led our JASA class in the early COVID lockdown. Not sure what happened to our class puzzle, but both instructors were smart and engaging. Great memories, thanks to you both.

I am fully expecting this puzzle to be universally loved and adored.

I certainly did.

I do love me a good squirmy rebus-infested puzzle. 
This one was a little basic, what with the circles and all, but that's OK.

At first I was a bit let down by the rebuses being all the same, as well as having their location neatly marked on the grid. Ah, but then came the twist - the down answers were ROAD, BOULEVARD, AVENUE and STREET, all with potholes. How ingenious! It's true that this was an unusual Thursday in that it didn't require furrowing my own brows in deep thought, but I think beginners might furrow theirs, and it's fair that they should have an introduction to rebus puzzles. I think this was a very nice puzzle, with a well executed idea and clever fill, and I thank Natan Last and the J.A.S.A. Crossword Class for delivering a gem! To those who would rather see rebus puzzles go by the way of dinosaurs, I respectfully think of you when I see DREAM ON in the grid. I also think of Depeche Mode - https://youtu.be/7dgrMSTalZ0?si=8UXukua14FHWHKrJ

Sorry, @David B from Albany. I see they have decided to really eliminate your interesting comment about the mini yesterday which appeared as the first comment when today‚Äôs column was erroneously published a day early. I‚Äôm a bit surprised no one else commented on this one. (In spite of BA‚Äôs protests, I‚Äôm of the view that your point was a valid one‚Ä¶even if M-W had a cop-out excuse for accepting this spelling). https://nytimes.com/shared/comment/44ne21?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share

Not too bad. The rebus was easy to work out, and it was a nice touch having them in theme answers‚ÄîSTREET, AVENUE, etc. 

The fill was good, but the puzzle was easy for a Thursday.

Personally, I didn't like AFTS as an answer. YMMV.

7.5/10

What a brilliant job of road contruction this was, filling all those STREETwise POTholes with clues that were Thursday worthy and SLY, in the best tradition of crossword puzzles.   

Clearly these constructors are not in their DOTAGE.  I bow to their grasp of the complexity and inspiration that were required to give us this gem.  Thank you, Mr. Last, and the jazzy JASA class that gave us this one.

I loved this. I caught on almost immediately with family hiring, confirmed it with Dick and Jane, and began understanding the down answers with Mr. Frost. 

And a new personal best, less than half my average time. 

In sync with this one!
I couldn‚Äôt quite place it, but anyone else feel like they‚Äôd seen 13D somewhere before?

Time was 42% less than average.  Solved this somewhat aggressively, throwing down answers that weren‚Äôt gimmes, but turned out to be correct. 

Nice aha moment when I got the theme.

Left the potholes open until the end on the chance they didn‚Äôt need to be filled in.
I had _UCK for the word repeated in children‚Äôs games and was worried about modern kids for a moment.

"Dream On" (Aerosmith), "Maneater" (Hall & Oates), The Beegees, "Mesopotamia" (B-52s), "Come Undone" (Duran Duran)...I'm getting the sense that this JASA crowd is slightly younger than I'd have guessed, in their sixties -- or maybe that's what people far into their dotage think is hot right now! Well, OK Daddio, I'll wipe the cobwebs off my eponymous Duran Duran...

Ah, it'll take a little time
Might take a little crime to come undone
Now we'll try to stay blind to the hope and fear outside
Hey child, stay wilder than the wind and blow me in to cry...

Here in Pittsburgh, the Pothole Capital of the World, most of our streets are bedizened with tarry pancakes of blobby patches which themselves have gotten patched, and the introduction of speed bumps to several of our bumpy boulevards a few years ago was met with incredulity by the local denizens: "We don't need no stinkin' speed bumps!"

A pothole developed in the alley behind our garage and soon had the dimensions of a small grave. I bought a bag of cold mix asphalt and began filling it but realized it wasn't going to be enough. Thankfully a neighbor had set out a carton of books: Ann Coulter, Glen Beck, Bill O'Reilly...I grabbed a dozen and through them in the hole. But the lack of content in those books made the hole collapse within a week and I ended up having to do it De Novo, with Emma Goldman, Rosa Luxembourg, Walt Whitman and Saul Alinsky. Haven't had a problem since.

I took the road less graveled
And that made all the smoothness.

(But the forecast calls for Frost.)
Really awful: POT as a rebus (maybe POTREZEBIE for old-time Mad aficionados). But perhaps an apt intro to the age of MAGA.

When my husband and I bought our house, the realtor referred to it as a ‚Äústarter‚Äù home. Apparently, we were meant to learn the basics of homeownership here, then move on to something bigger and more challenging. 

I guess we didn‚Äôt learn our lessons, because we‚Äôre still here. (Actually, we just really like our house.) But in that spirit, I think this puzzle would make a great ‚Äústarter rebus‚Äù. It‚Äôs intuitive and easy to grasp. If the inability to squeeze SEE SPOT RUN into 15A causes a little uncertainty, having the inability to squeeze NEPOTISM into the *very next clue* is like a gentle guiding hand. And then the circles‚Ä¶

This is not to say I thought the puzzle was too easy, or boring. On the contrary, I thought it was a fun drive. Having the potholes scattered among the various thoroughfares was a clever bonus. And the clues were definitely challenging enough to be engaging. 

This puzzle probably won‚Äôt sway anyone who is already determined to hate rebuses. But for anyone else, and especially those who are new to the concept, I think this is a great example to show just how much fun it can be to navigate a rebus puzzle. Just watch out for the potholes!

What a clever one Mr Last and the JASA class have created here. I left the holes open until the very end, then filled the POT (so to speak) to earn the gold star. As a former resident of Wisconsin, I got a good chuckle as the theme began to come into view. Some of those potholes could swallow a car ü§£ On the other hand, The Sunset in the West isn‚Äôt looking quite the same these days. We were glued to the TV today yet again as another fire broke out in the far reaches of the LA area and remains uncontained and 31,000 additional people had to evacuate. Hopefully I will wake up to better news in the morning. As always, thank you to Mr Last and the JASA class for brightening my day with your puzzle.

Good clean fun!

EROICA/ECSEGAR had me stuck for a bit.

Natan Last and the J.A.S.A. Crossword Class sounds like the name of an avantgarde music band üòÄ I enjoyed the puzzle in general, and caught on to the rebus instantly thanks to MESO(POT)AMIA. I needed quite a few lookups though, as the grid relied on proper names and trivia to a greater extent than I'd like. I also only got the Dick and Jane (whatever that is) line because it was a themed entry. Yesterday @Tom asked me why I wrote of the fall of Polish "communism" with those quotation marks, but because of time zones by then I was sound asleep and only saw the question today: I thought I'd reply here. @Tom It was just a dictatorship, an oligarchy, posing as a communist utopia. It was not communism. If anything, it was closer to socialism, but wasn't really socialist, either. Almost everything about the system and its regime was fake, and almost everybody over here knew it. The great absurdist director Stanis≈Çaw Bareja captured the spirit of "communist" Poland perfectly in his grotesque comedies. Here's his wiki entry, with kinks to his works: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stanis%C5%82aw_Bareja However, I'm not sure how any of that can be understandable to somebody who has not experienced that world themselves, even as a child, like I did. Even my wife's sister, who was born in 1990, after the fall of "communism", and 10 years later than my wife an I, doesn't get what Bareja's films and series are really about. So please, take my word for it ü§™

"Wiimote" is a casual name that everyone assumed was official. Nintendo always called it the Wii Remote (or was meant to). A different company had earlier trademarked "Weemote" for their TV remote for young children, so Nintendo itself was careful to avoid that name.

Pretty darn amusing. Caught the rebus on NE(POT)ISM so it was fairly smooth after that. My ROAD bumps was the crossing of ECSEGAR and EROICA.

That J.A.S.A. crossword construction class sounds pretty cool. I imagined retired academics in their DOTAGE keeping their minds sharp. ‚ÄúGood for them,‚Äù I thought. That‚Äôs until Deb said 55 and up. Then I realized I, too, am a retired academic in my DOTAGE keeping my mind sharp! üôáüèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è If I think I‚Äôm still young, I‚Äôd better DREAMON!

On a different note, I know there won‚Äôt be any POTHOLES on the ROADs in my South Carolina hometown that is still blanketed with snow. Why? Because they have no snow plows or salt to clear the streets. Everyone is supposed to just stay home. To be fair, it hasn‚Äôt snowed there in 25 years, and rarely before then.

Stay warm and dry!

Is it possible to have an option in the settings to indicate that there are rebus tiles?  

Personally, it's neither enjoyable or interesting, and the moment I realize they are in the possible, I feel frustration.

Ty

Fun one! Something clicked immediately when I knew it had to be ‚ÄúSee Spot Run‚Äù. (Some of us are showing our age there, no doubt.) Like some others, a personal best time, and my first sub-15-minute Thursday! üòÅ

Weird sensation when completing this puzzle.   It started out feeling very difficult.   Somewhere along the way something clicked and I was able to start it and eventually solve it.  When some I thought my time was going to be well below my average, but when I looked at the timer results I was stoked to see that I actually crushed it...finishin the puzzle it in just over half of my normal time.

Very original and very fun. Thank you, Natan et al. Enjoyed it a lot. I started on the grid midway through my (normally verboten) third cup of coffee‚Äîand so in warp-speed mode‚Äîbut I got tripped up by the Beatles‚Äô having the same number of letters as the BEE GEES. Every reference to a 7-letter band from before my generation‚Äôs music era is going to be the Beatles, dontchaknow. Except that Robin Gibb had rolled over into my childhood. As a tween, maybe a little younger, I came across his Secret Agent album while at a record store with my dad. Remember, GenXers, when you could put on headphones and listen to CDs right in the store? Well, I went home with Secret Agent. Lemme tellya, Robin had tailor-written ‚ÄúIn Your Diary‚Äù for slumber parties. Could you have a better song to play Mansion Apartment Shack or House to or stuff your face with cold pizza to? I distinctly remember that there was no doubt left by the time morning rolled around that I was going to marry Derek from third period. üé∂ ‚ÄúIn my diary, I did imagine, I did imagine his face.‚Äù üé∂ (With apologies to my Better Half. Sorry, hon.) And for those of you whose inner tween is still alive and well: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=XJjIAGQ5ULo

I enjoyed this one - Beethoven instead of rapper, Frost instead of a baseball hero! I learnt all about Popeye - memories of childhood, when we had no idea what spinach was, it didn't arrive in Scotland for a long, long time after. 

But it's Every Good Boy Deserves Favour and we started with 
Janet and John.
Fun smooth solve, except for the POTHOLES. Learning how drive in Manhattan,  mom always told me that if you drive over them fast enough, you don't feel them.

I'm normally average at crosswords, but being singaporean, I immediately got MAPOTOFU, and had no hesitation entering the rebus. I didn't know a lot of the words, but the amazingly great start led to a 24 minute finish with no hints or clues. I wonder if any other enjoyer of asian food experienced the same thing

Nice to get the gimmick early ish to help with other solves. Some obscure stuff but balanced overall. My great bugbear with the NYT crossword remains the tendency to use ‚Äúinformally‚Äù or ‚Äúin brief‚Äù when what they mean is they‚Äôre about to brutalise a word beyond common recognition to get it into the grid. I‚Äôve spent many AFTS grumbling about this.

Crossword Revolution D2:  POTHOLE

Yes, early on, this quiet but potentially mighty revolution has hit a pothole.  All revolutions do eventually.  Better to get it out of the way early.

* A Crosswords Saved the Day ‚Ñ¢ production.  All rights reserved, especially the right to absurdity.

Strands Thread.  Express no spoilers until after the View All Replies button please: 


Strands #326
‚ÄúUdderly delicious‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ


Upper left word was a head scratcher at first.
55 plus eh.  Well these whippersnappers at J.A.S.A sure came up with a clever and fun theme.  Clue difficulty could have been dialed up a bit but a fine morning solve nonetheless.  Many thanks.

Look. Look, look. Look, look, look. I learned to read with Dick and Jane in the NYC public school system in the 50s. Of course I knew they didn't live in Brooklyn. They lived somewhere near The Beaver.

This was fun.

I started out thinking something was off when NEPOTISM didn't fit, and by MESOPOTAMIA I was sure of it, so I was able to fill in the POTHOLES throughout. Was it a coincidence that I was dealing with POTHOLES the morning after we decided to put more money into our paving budget? Sure, probably, but a fun coincidence it was.

Looking at my stats I see that Thursday has the widest spread between my best and my average, enabling me to come in at about double my best and half my average today. Not hard, but the rebuses and the clever placement of the POTHOLES in the middle of thoroughfares was worth it.

Thanks!

Great job! 

As I plopped in the last letter, 
I remembered one of my favorite,
mostly forgotten words-

finifugal.

(adjective, English)
hating endings; 
of someone who tries to avoid or
prolong the final moments of a story,
relationship, or some other journey.

Like a clever Thursday puzzle.

Have a wonderful day all!
A clever puzzle. Perhaps because I am "over 55" myself, I found it much easier than the usual Thursday.

That was fun. A relatable theme surrounded by fun/interesting fill.
TIL the name of Hawaiian chips (crisps?), Tibetan dumplings and Sichuan bean curd;  the last doesn‚Äôt appeal to me quite as much as not a fan of tofu.

As I live up a farm track the POTHOLES are our responsibility. We‚Äôre constantly redoing them, but a combination of heavy farm equipment and the incessant rain undoes our work in the blink of an eye.

In all of Crosslandia‚Äôs major venues, this is only the second pothole-themed puzzle.  The first, by Tracy Gray (10/22/15), had a different gimmick, and a terrific one at that, worth checking out.

Tracy‚Äôs lovely gimmick didn‚Äôt include the potholes interrupting traffic arteries, like today‚Äôs  does ‚Äì a terrific touch, IMO.  I also like that the potholes are circled, because, to me at least, the tops of holes are stereotypically circular.

My fill-in was enhanced by appealing words and phrases: BARFLY, PETAL, DREAM ON, COME UNDONE.  Also, sweet to see BEEGEE and TEEPEE, words made of letter sounds.

I love the idea of a group of people making a puzzle, all motivated by making it the best it can be, and guided by that ethos, brainstorming the theme, best answers, and best clues.  

Every J.A.S.A. puzzle I‚Äôve done has felt like it has been made like this.  It‚Äôs a great credit not only to the talents of the students, but to the teacher, who fosters that best-it-can-be climate.

So, bravo to you all, congratulations on being published NYT constructors, and thank you for a smile-producing outing today!

Nice puzzle and a clever theme. A mostly typical Thursday workout for me, but I remained baffled about the rebus squares for a while as they weren't working both ways. And there were a couple of completely unfamiliar entries - MAPOTOFU notably. Finally working out the reveal and pondering for a moment was a terrific aha moment when I finally caught on.

Sort of cute puzzle find today. I'll put that in a reply. 

...

Since Mr. Connell has not been posting as frequently, a little bit of unsolicited advice I picked up from him:

In any puzzle with rebuses, or in which there are squares which must be filled in in some "tricksy" format, and when you're unsure exactly what formats might be deemed "acceptable," erase one square of which you have absolute certainty--1A/1D is always a good one--until the very last, then reenter it.
BTW, I loved the chutzpah this group of 55+ individuals showed by ironically placing DOTAGE, clued [Years of decline], in the grid of a PUBLISHED NYT PUZZLE!

A fun and easier-than-usual Thursday for me. I took the JASA class remotely during lockdown and loved it. Sadly, as far as I know, our class's puzzle was never published. I got really fired up about constructing, but have yet to actually make my own puzzle. Kudos to this group!

A little story:
One snowy afternoon, a couple winters ago, my Partner and I were sitting in the living room of our place Up North--I was reading a novel, he was reading news on his i-pad.
"Here's a story--Margaret Atwood responds to her novels being included on a list of books banned in Florida County Public Schools." (She was flattered.)

"What else was on the list?"

"*Beloved*, by Toni Morrison, *Fun Home* by Alison Bechdel . . . yadda yadda . . ., and *Snow Falling on Cedars* by Stephen Guterson."

I raised the book I had in my hand. 
"Why was it banned, did they say?"

"Profanity and sexual content."
"Yeah, right." 

A beautiful novel, I may whole-heartedly recommend. (I have not seen the movie.)

And we've only just seen the beginning.

Great puzzle today.
Dinner tonight‚Ä¶Mopotofu or Mess o potamia?

Boy, did I laugh when I figured out the secret of SKIPPING the POT holes on the down entries! And answers just kept popping into my head throughout. Intuition is wonderful. 
Many have written that it's an easy Thursday puzzle, but that was okay by me. Usually I'm fading by now and this was a lift!

Though  I have a certain antipathy to rebuses that generate nonsense in one or other direction, I actually liked this one, and enjoyed the whole puzzle, despite a protracted mental blank about EVENTS in the Declaration of Independence.
The usage of DE NOVO to mean [All over again] was new to me---I've only ever seen it used meaning "For the first time".

Fun fact:  It is thought that MESOpotAMIA is home to the first roads and presumably the first POT HOLES.

Fun one!  Love the Thursday puzzles!

Just now learned (again, surely?) that furlong comes from the length of a furrow in a farmer‚Äôs field. So, trying to look on the bright side of uneven roads: if you‚Äôre in a rut, maybe you‚Äôre actually a race horse, running for the roses!

There‚Äôs a hole in my puzzle, dear Liza, dear Liza.
With what shall I fill it? (See rebus instructions)

A fun one!

Thanks for the ear worm‚Ä¶ Hall & Oates ‚ÄúShe‚Äôll only come out at night‚Äù.

Great puzzle today by Natan Last and the J.A.SA. Crossword Class!

Puzzle? Hah! This is a POT party.

Died at the intersection of Popeye and Beethoven. 

Snow is almost gone here in Southern Miss.

Nice one Natan, Thank you

The constructors of this puzzle are clearly not in their DOTAGE just yet. Well done!

As for the theme, we have yet to enter true pothole season here in MN. They have the tendency to appear literally overnight. Sometimes they're big enough to swallow my Fiesta whole.
A little easy for a Thursday but such a delight!
Loved this puzzle! It's just too bad they couldn't include the word "Indianapolis," since we're the Crossroads of America.

So many fun songs inspired by a region: https://youtube.com/watch?v=Hq6IJ94A7pQ https://youtube.com/watch?v=WHvwrBI4_lc (Thanks to @Harmon for reminding me of the latter) OTOH, here's a little ditty from before Every Good Boy Did Fine: https://youtube.com/watch?v=x-Yq_6c9bKg

Had to read "Either of two diverging in a Robert Frost poem" carefully, but once I did the puzzle's theme became apparent, since SEESPOTRUN was a gimme. This made the rest of the puzzle very easy, since I surmised that POT would fill each "hole" and that the corresponding verticals would be synonyms for ROAD.

That said, I'm glad I knew EROICA, since ECSEGAR was gone from my memory.

Cute theme, but one that almost reveals too much once it's figured out.
‚Äúmapofu‚Äù is an awful contraction of mapo tofu

I wish WE could have a Crossword Class here in our Village; you have to be 60 or older to get in unless you're here to perform, teach, or otherwise fill our time...as if we don't have enough to do what with picking up our prescriptions and going to our doctors' appointments.  

Where was I?  Oh, the puzzle!  Wow... Sichuan, Tibetan, Korean, Japanese, and Polynesian...  Natan Last needs to hold class AFTER, not before, mealtime.  

I've never heard of MAPO TOFU, and tht was the sole clue/entry to give me pause.  
10D was my fave; new to me!  
BTW, Thanks for choosing novels I have read and remember.  
And now....in the words of Emeril, BAM!
Fun puzzle, smart and not precious, but a little too easy for Thursday.
For those of you who speed through crosswords, you might like this New Yorker cartoon in the current issue: https://newyorker.com/cartoon/a60276
32A: Its Mesopotamia, but it doesn't fit on the crossword for some reason

THIS is how you use rebuses! Nice. 

However, utterly confused why they ran this one on a Thursday when it‚Äôs definitely Tuesday material. Or maybe we‚Äôre all just getting better at solving! :)
Nice Thursday. Although if you aren‚Äôt overly familiar with Beethoven or Popeye you‚Äôll be left guessing.

Whenever I actually manage to solve a Thursday I come to the comments and inevitably find out it was an easy one. Oh well. I thought this was clever and quite fast and fun with a few hiccups to keep it interesting.
Theme clicked almost immediately but there was enough trivia that I didn't break any records

Thursday‚Äôs 3 down should be ‚Äúroad‚Äù but to fit 15 across, it is ‚Äúropad‚Äù. I could not find a definition for ‚Äúropad‚Äù. When I checked the puzzle, ‚Äúropad‚Äù was correct. Please define ‚Äúropad‚Äù.

A relatable puzzle indeed! In Montreal there are the many new potholes that open up each spring, and also the eternal potholes that never get fixed (they just get a little bit bigger each year). So I got the theme quite quickly. 

Maybe I should make a puzzle with an orange cone theme. These have surpassed potholes as a symbol of Montreal, which is now referred to as Coney Island II.

A knott(hole)y one indeed. 

I saw the trick early on but it wasn't till I filled in all the other blanks that I realized I had to manually insert the rebus. I thought as they were "holes" they didn't need to be entered. 

Cost me about ten minutes solve time.
I didn't realize the potholes were all in "street" clues until I finished the puzzle and read the article. Cleverly done!

Very fun, very cute theme with solid wordplay throughout. A bit easy for a Thursday but I won‚Äôt complain!

I ended on a bit of a sour note however‚ÄîMAPO TOFU is outside my wheelhouse and AFTS felt a bit wonky. That‚Äôs my only nit to pick though, otherwise an excellent puzzle, J.A.S.A. class!

Hi.  I got to this late and I'm sure everything has been covered.  The puzzle was fine, and the theme was okay I guess, but the whole thing seemed way too easy for Thursday.  This felt like a mildly challenging Tuesday to me...  I did like the moment where I thought "wait, road should be singular here, not roads," before it became clear.

Thanks.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Considering how clunky and computer-y the last couple Thursdays have been, I'll take my smooth, enjoyable, 8-minute solve and move on.

"Bee-dazzler" for PETAL was just weird, almost a cheap stunt. Somebody in the group must have really liked it, and the rest didn't want to hurt their feelings. I cannot imagine construction by committee, but the rebus/theme held everything together nicely. Surprised that nobody has mentioned PDQ Bach's EROtICA Variations (For Banned Instruments) so here you go: https://youtube.com/watch?v=dzdkghhJMOs

Yes it was only the easy side, but when I read the story behind the constructors, it warmed my heart. I love that this was a collab with a center for the aging. I lost my parents back-to-back two years ago, and they were both avid, daily NYT puzzlers. They would so have loved to take part in this project! ü•∞ A fun theme, a nice break from the earlier puzzles in the week, and now I am ready for the challenges in the next two days‚Äô worth.

Wow!  Thirty eight minutes!  Was that easy or am I just getting better?   Although like other here I'd never heard of mapo tofu, and was today-years-old when I learned that "cence" is a word, and a verb.  Thanks Natan and friends!
11:30, and to everyone here who has not had Mapo Tofu: you are absolutely missing out. Truly one of the best dishes in the entire world.
Now this is how a rebus puzzle should be!
I really can't complain about the puzzle (but I do hate to see "rebus creep").
Lots of humble-bragging today; glad everyone did so well.

Ok, I'm going to start boring myself soon. Ha - as if! 

I'll never stop being amazed when I complete the crossword without any lookups. For the first time this week and today makes it the third day in a row. ü§Ø I wonder if solving it later in the day means I'm a bit more patient? There were a few times I was so tempted to wander into Googleland especially with the Americanisms but I resisted and persisted and subsisted! (If that isn't a saying, I'm patenting it ASAP.

No chance I'll manage this tomorrow - Fridays and Saturdays give me palpitations - but I'm pleased as punch right now. Even after reading a comment from someone saying it was rather easy and finished in eight mins. Only 40mins quicker than me but he's in Texas and I expect knowing the start of the Declaration of Independence wasn't a five-min process of elimination ü§£

Hats of the constructors for making a rebus puzzle that was both clever and fun! Mazel! üëèüèæ

I finished a puzzle from the archive (Jan 24, 1995) right before I started this one and there was a clue referencing ETHAN Frome in that one as well üò≥ I know clues/answers are often recycled but how spooky it was to see that back to back yet 30 years apart 

Also what a fun rebus! I caught onto it quickly and was rather proud of myself ‚ò∫Ô∏è
I never thought the NYT would go to "POT" in my lifetime. Fun puzzle!
Hmm. The puzzle references the Beatles, the BeeGees, Beethoven, Hall & Oates . . . but the ear worm is from The Guess Who. https://youtube.com/watch?v=8BkmzexdIGs She's COME UNDONE.
Cute puzzle!  I love Thursdays.

I had "Eddie" as in "Eddie Ate Dynamite, Good Bye Eddie," a mnemonic for remembering guitar strings, E-A-D-G-B-E. That locked up the NW corner for a bit. I can't be the only one, right?

The Popeye reference today has induced a bit of discussion here about Popeye's enthusiasm for spinach, which sent me down a rather marvellous rabbit hole. There's a narrative associated with this that some here may know---about a German researcher who misplaced a decimal point, thereby suggesting that spinach contained about ten times more iron than it actually does, which in turn fed into a perception of spinach as a superfood, which in turn led to Popeye's superpower. Very little of that turns out to actually be true, and much of it arises from an entertaining but unreferenced piece published in a Christmas edition of the British Medical Journal in the early '80s, which I recall reading at the time. But this unfounded story has launched a HUGE amount of documentary research, culminating in 2019 with an 83-page article with 367 references, entitled "Spinach in Blunderland: How the myth that spinach is rich in iron became an urban academic legend" https://tinyurl.com/3h3rmfny Several pages consist almost entirely of footnotes! It's an undiluted joy, if you're one of that small number of people who take joy from erudite papers about recondite topics.

@Andrzej My husband says the same thing. He was born and raised about 20 minutes south of Tylicz, Poland, just across the Slovak border.  He was raised there in the early 1970s so his memories of that era are vivid.  He says there was no ideology other than corruption, fear and oppression. 

He said HBO series *Chernobyl* perfectly captured the look and feel of his life there during that time. His stories ‚Äî even of what he had to do to leave ‚Äî are fascinating to my American brain.

@Andrzej 
Dick and Jane refers to a series of children's books from (I think) the late 1940s aimed at those just learning to read. They contained simple yet inane sentences like "See Spot run! Run, Spot, run!" Even at age six I knew that no child talked that way. Fortunately they were being phased out by then. I know my older siblings had them. To be fair, we all turned out literate in the end.
Teresa, 1930! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dick_and_Jane

@Barry Ancona 

One wonders if the author made a bet with somebody that she could get away with publishing a book about having fun with Dick... I once bet my best mate I could sneak a reference to my favorite childhood comic book into one of my peer reviewed articles on law and public administration - and sure enough, I managed to achieve the feat ü§£

@Teresa 
The "Look-Say" Method dated to the 1920's.  No phonics were taught.  It was based on suspect reasoning that flew in the face of experience and the origins of written language, but it somehow took hold and left children who did not--by themselves--figure out the "trick" (the sound-symbol relationship) unable to read new words.  It held sway far too long.  I am baffled by the affection some people express for the "Dick and Jane" books.  (BTW, I taught special education...and adult basic reading, having many students for whom phonics were a revelation....)
@Andrzej - I appreciated the air quotes. The hollowness of that place and time was what it was. It still is in many other places!

@Teresa I learned to read in first grade in 1968, and I loved Dick and Jane with all my heart.  Although I couldn't have expressed it at the time, I recognized the texts as didactic and not meant to reflect real speech.  Together with Mrs. Howell's phonics worksheets (dittos at that time), they catapulted me into reading very effectively.  By the end of first grade I could read the easier children's classic novels and the "color" fairy books with no help at all.  Very soon I was a full fledged reader whose library card was never idle.  As an English teacher, I wish more children were taught to read using this practical combination of "see and say" and phonics.  On another note:  Have you ever read a novel where the characters spoke as people do in real life?  "Run, Spot, run"  is literary genius by comparison.

@Andrzej As a naive seventeen-year-old girl I had the great good luck to go on a study program that included three weeks in the GDR (Dresden, Potsdam, and East Berlin).  I left wiser than I came, and it was the beginning of my political awakening.

@Andrzej Thanks for the thoughtful, and thought-provoking, reply.  A colleague and friend, Marek, from my old job is a medical doctor in Poland.  He was born in the 1960s, and he had some similar views to yours on the nature of ‚Äúcommunism‚Äù in Poland.  

In addition to Stanis≈Çaw Barej, are there other writers who have shed light on that era, and what it may mean for Europe today?

@Tamal I wonder if this is actually a viable solution. I love rebus puzzles, and figuring out that there's a rebus is part of the fun for many of us. @Oikofuge 
It's really DE NOVO al Fin√©; I've only seen it in a few scores.  Most of the time it's one of the other phrases or just the symbols which mean the same thing, or which call for repeating certain passages (making the performance longer/interminable.)

@Mean Old Lady 

It's medical Latin to me. Diseases arise "de novo" when they have not been present previously---for instance, a disease that is usually inherited which suddenly appears in a family because of a mutated gene in one individual.
@Oikofuge - it still isn‚Äôt ‚Äúfor the first time,‚Äù it is ‚Äúfor the first time again‚Äù - other families had the mutation before. De novo always denotes going back to the starting line.
@Oikofuge - it never meant ‚Äúfor the first time‚Äù, both in Latin and in English / legalese. It has always meant ‚Äústart over from the beginning.‚Äù https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pachisi

@David Connell Interesting argument, and I take your point about most "new" genetic conditions being "new" only to that family, but I'm unconvinced, both because of the broader evidence, and my trusty Oxford English Dictionary. One of the primary drivers of evolution is described as "de novo mutation"---that is, mutation that produces features that have never existed before. The FDA has a "de novo" approval system for completely novel medical devices, separate from its system for new versions of existing applications. "De novo domestication" is the process of using genetic manipulation (either in the lab or by cross breeding) to domesticate species that have not previously been domesticated. "De novo synthesis of life" is the construction of an entirely new life form from chemical components. (https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.accounts.1c00534) Confirming all this, we find that, in addition to its definitions implying "all over again", the OED has an entry for the use of "de novo" as an adjective meaning "new, fresh". (What was the relevance of the Pachisi link, BTW?)

@Justin 
And those ROADS are still there because they really knew how to build 'em to last!  That was because the water-soluble asphault had yet to be invented.
